entry.title: Heart Failure with preserved ejection fraction: recent concepts in diagnosis, machanisms and management
entry.content:
Abstract

  1. One-half of all patients with heart failure (HF) have heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

  2. Among patients with HF, the proportion of hospitalizations and deaths due to cardiac causes decrease as LVEF increases.

  3. Medication classes that have been efficacious in HFrEF have been less so at higher LVEF ranges.

  4. These observations reflect the burden of non-cardiac comorbidities as LVEF increases.

  5. Treatment with sodium-glucose cotransporter two inhibitors reduce the risk of composite cardiovascular events, driven by reduced HF hospitalizations; renin-angiotensin-aldosterone blockers and angiotensin-neprilysin inhibitors result in a minor reduction in HF hospitalizations.

  6. Classification based on phenotypes may facilitate a more targeted approach to
    treatment than LVEF categorization, which     sets arbitrary cut-points when LVEF is a continuum**.

    The evolving definition of HFpEF

    Recently re-labeled as ‘mildly reduced’ for LVEF 40-50%. HFpEF is now defined by normal LVEF ( 50%) along with signs and symptoms of heart failure after exclusion of prior reduced LVEF and treatable underlying conditions. However, these classifications of HF defined by arbitrary cut-points in LVEF do not appear consistent with recent evidence, which points to a gradual shift in underlying mechanisms, phenotypes, and response to therapy as LVEF increases, with considerable overlap.

    Current diagnostic approach and its limitations

    HFpEF can be defined theoretically as the presence of elevated left ventricular (LV) filling
    pressure at rest or during exercise     with normal LVEF. Most guidelines explain HFpEF clinically as (i) the presence of symptoms and signs of HF; (ii) an LVEF ≥ 50%, (iii) careful exclusion of “HFpEF mimickers,” and (iv) evidence of elevated left ventricular (LV)
    filling pressure or non-invasive correlates     (elevated E/e ratio, increased left atrial volume,
    elevated natriuretic peptides [NP]).

    Several “HFpEF” randomized clinical trials(RCTs) have used lower LVEF cut-offs (40-45%) to maximize event rates and thus attain statistical power.

    NP levels may not always guide diagnosis as they tend to be lower in HFpEF than HFrEF, likely due to lower diastolic wall stress and a higher prevalence of obesity.

    While these criteria rely on measurements at rest, left-sided filling pressures increase only with exercise in many patients with HFpEF; patients who do not experience dyspnea and demonstrate signs of elevated LV filling pressure at rest require advanced testing such as exercise echocardiography or invasive exercise hemodynamic to unmask abnormal diastolic reserve.

    E/e’ during exercise has been shown to correlate reasonably well with invasively measured pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP).

    Invasive hemodynamics directly measures PCPW during exercise, although even the diagnostic threshold is still debated (exercise PCWP≥25 mmHg or ΔPCWP/Δcardiac output slope2.0 mmHg/L/min).

    Two HFpEF diagnostic algorithms -the H2FPEF score and the European Society of Cardiology HFA-PEFF algorithm combine clinical characteristics and diagnostic parameters to distinguish HFpEF from non-cardiac dyspnea.

    Validation of these scores against invasive hemodynamics demonstrated good performance: the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve was 0.73-0.74. Still, up to 23% of patients were misclassified in both scores, typically in patients with low scores who met invasive HFpEF criteria. Thus, low scores may not exclude HFpEF. Furthermore, a substantial proportion of patients have an intermediate probability for HFpEF using this classification system and require further testing.

    HFpEF mimickers and specific cardiac aetiologies of HFpEF

    “HFpEF mimickers” such as lung disease, pulmonary embolism, right-sided heart failure secondary to pulmonary hypertension, and renal failure can present similar symptoms and signs. These can be classified into diseases affecting the myocardium and altering cardiac loading conditions.

    Recent Insights in HFpEF Pathophysiology

    In a normal LV, volume increases during diastole are accompanied by minimal pressure increases due to enhanced diastolic suction; LV end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) remains regular with exercise.

    In HFpEF, due to increased chamber stiffness, the diastolic pressure-volume relationship is shifted upwards and left compared to a normal LV. Volume changes thus lead to more significant increases in LVEDP.

    Additionally, in most HFpEF patients, the exercise-induced increase in cardiac output is blunted due to poor contractile reserve and chronotropic incompetence. In overt HFpEF, the elevated LVEDP persists at rest, resulting in poor exercise tolerance.

    Cardiac and non-cardiac mechanisms

    Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, sleep-disordered breathing, and lung parenchymal disease can result in pulmonary hypertension, eventually leading to RV failure.

    Anemia is a common comorbidity, contributing to exercise intolerance and increased mortality.

    Peripheral vascular dysfunction is frequent and is postulated to play a role in skeletal muscle dysfunction due to impaired oxygen delivery and extraction.

    Chronic kidney disease is present in 50% of patients, and impaired fluid homeostasis in HFpEF is influenced by renal dysfunction.

    Obesity is both a common comorbidity and a risk factor for developing HFpEF.

    HFpEF phenotypes

    As LVEF increases, patients with HF are more commonly women; more commonly have hypertension and atrial fibrillation; less commonly have ischemic heart disease; and have lower NP levels.

    Lifestyle-based therapy

  7. In a small RCT in obese patients with HFpEF, a calorie restricted diet alone or in combination with exercise training(ET) was associated with significant weight loss and an increase in absolute peak oxygen consumption (VO2peak).

  8. A low sodium diet has been associated with favorable hemodynamic changes in HFpEF.
  9. ET has beneficial effects in HFpEF and associated comorbidities such as atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease. (Both standard moderate continuous training to high intensity interval training). However, the benefit in VO2peak was not
    sustained during a 9-month home-based supervised extension of training    .

  10. A 6-month exercise program combining supervised and home-based aerobic exercise resulted in a significant decrease in the recurrence of atrial fibrillation and a reduction in symptom severity at 12 months.

    Medical therapy

  11. To date, no medical therapy has demonstrated a reduction in CV death in trials of HFpEF, suggesting the relatively large burden of noncardiac mortality in this group.

  12. Despite a lack of robust evidence, diuretics have been the mainstay of HFpEF management and are recommended for relief of symptoms due to volume overload.
  13. Beta blockers are often prescribed in HFpEF to treat comorbidities such as coronary artery disease and atrial fibrillation. A meta-analysis of three medium-sized RCTs demonstrated a reduction in all-cause mortality, but a vast majority had LVEF <50%. Additionally, beta-blocker type may have differential effects across HFpEF phenotypes.
  14. Renin angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors (RAASi) and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs) have an established role in HFrEF, but have been less effective in HFpEF.
  15. Trials of angiotensin-converting enzyme receptor inhibitors (ACEi) and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) have failed to show a significant reduction in all- cause or CV death in HFpEF, but have decreased the risk of HF hospitalization.
  16. The Treatment of Preserved Cardiac Function HF With an Aldosterone Antagonist (TOPCAT) trial of the MRA spironolactone in HFpEF,failed to show an overall benefit in the primary composite outcome of CV death or HF hospitalization. However, in an exploratory analysis including only patients from the Americas, a small benefit on the primary outcome was noticed.
  17. In both TOPCAT and the TOPCAT-Americas subgroup, spironolactone was associated with a reduced risk of HF hospitalization.
  18. Machine learning analysis of the TOPCAT trial identified a phenotype characterized by obesity, diabetes, renal disease, and inflammation that exhibited higher CV risk and a better response to spironolactone treatment.
  19. The angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) sacubitril-valsartan did not reduce the composite of CV death or total HF hospitalizations in patients with HF and LVEF ≥45% relative to valsartan in the Prospective Comparison of ARNI With ARB on Global Outcomes in HFpEF (PARAGON-HF) trial, but significantly reduced HF hospitalizations.
  20. Patients with elevated troponin or recent HF hospitalization were at higher CV risk and were more likely to benefit from ARNI. Also, benefits were higher in patients previously using MRA.
  21. These HFpEF phenotypes –more likely to be associated with structural heart disease and volume overload- may be more responsive to ARNI treatment.
  22. In the EMPEROR-Preserved trial, sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitor (SGLT2i) empagliflozin reduced the risk of composite CV death or total HF hospitalization in HF with LVEF 40%. There was no statistically significant interaction between LVEF and the primary outcome in the trial, but benefit did not extend beyond LVEF of 60% in subgroup analysis.

  23. In the Effect of Sotagliflozin on Cardiovascular Events in Patients with Type 2 Diabetes Post Worsening Heart Failure (SOLOIST-WHF) trial, the dual SGLT2 and SGLT1 inhibitor sotagliflozin reduced the primary outcome of CV death and HF hospitalizations in patients with diabetes and worsening HF (both HFrEF and HFpEF), driven by reduced HF hospitalizations.

    Sex and Racial differences

  24. Epidemiological studies and randomized trials demonstrate a female predominance in HFpEF (50-84%) due to differences in age and risk factors; adjusting for these differences males and females are at equal risk of developing HFpEF.

  25. In the TOPCAT-Americas trial, a post hoc analysis showed no sex differences in the primary composite outcome, but females had a greater reduction in all-cause mortality relative to males with spironolactone .
  26. In a prespecified sub-analysis of the PARAGON-HF trial, benefits of sacubitril-valsartan on the primary composite outcome (total HF hospitalizations and CV death) were sustained up to a higher LVEF in females (up to 60%) than in males (up to 45%).
  27. A meta-analysis of trials of RAAS inhibitors was consistent with this finding; the benefits of candesartan, spironolactone and sacubitril-valsartan were sustained to a higher LVEF in females than in males.

  28. There is no evidence from TOPCAT or EMPEROR-PRESERVED that there are racial differences in treatment effect of MRAs and SGLT2i’s, respectively.

    Integration of Remote Monitoring and Multidisciplinary Technology

    Implantable remote pulmonary artery (PA) pressure guided monitoring for patients with HFpEF, NYHA Class III symptoms and a prior hospitalization was associated with a 46% reduction in HF hospitalizations compared to routine care.

    The Hemodynamic-Guided Management of HF (GUIDE-HF) trial, testing whether this benefit extended to patients with NYHA class II- IV symptoms and without a prior history hospitalization found that PA pressure guided management did not reduce the composite endpoint of all-cause mortality and total HF events.

    Something interesting

  29. Patients with HFmrEF have similar pathophysiology and treatment responses as those with HFrEF.

  30. Cardiac amyloidosis, for example, is present in up to 13% of HFpEF patients on routine biopsy.

  31. A recently validated risk score can predict patients with HFpEF at risk of sudden cardiac death.

    [Adabag S, Langsetmo L. Sudden cardiac death risk prediction in heart failure with
    preserved ejection fraction. Heart Rhythm 2020;17:358–64. ]

    [doi:10.1016/j.hrthm.2019.12.009]

  32. Cardiomyocyte calcium homeostasis was markedly abnormal in diabetic and hypertensive HFpEF but not in ischemic HFpEF.

  33. Obese HFpEF patients have markedly different clinical, hemodynamic and molecular changes compared to non-obese HFpEF patients.

  34. HFpEF caused by microvascular inflammation, HFrEF caused by cardiomyocyte loss.

    Conclusion

    LVEF is a continuous variable, and response to HF therapies appears to be graded such that HF therapies – including beta-blockers, RAAS inhibitors, ARNI, and SGLT2i - that reduce both CV death and HF hospitalization at lower LVEFs are less effective at reducing death but continue to reduce HF hospitalization at higher LVEFs beyond 50%. This points to the noncardiac mechanisms that underpin or accompany HF as the LVEF increases, as well as differences in underlying pathophysiology.

    Questions

  35. While the complex interaction of all the proposed non-cardiac mechanisms remain unclear, they appear to shift from mechanisms in HFrEF at higher ranges of LVEF, with a gradual change in phenotype and a gradual decrease in the proportion of CV causes of hospitalization and death as LVEF increases.

    New Words

    algorithm;overt;amenable;supervise;discerning;in light of;entail;concomitant;trait;amenable

entry.title: Review: Regulatory RNAs in Heart Failure
entry.content:
Abstract: Introduce the main idea of the article

Regulatory RNA, which we propose abbreviating as reg RNA, can include both protein-coding and noncoding RNAs. We will address the regulation and functional role of messenger RNAs, microRNAs, long noncoding RNAs, and circular RNAs (reg RNAs) in heart failure.

Introduction: Introduce the current status of the diagnosis and treatment of HF and the urgency to focus on

There are two significant issues: (1) vast numbers of patients have the condition; and (2) despite treatment advances, the prognosis remains poor. In this article, we introduce the concept of regulatory RNAs (reg RNAs) and gather the current knowledge of the role of RNA molecules with regulatory functions (reg RNAs) in several pathophysiological pathways associated with heart failure, namely cardiac hypertrophy, inflammation, regeneration, and angiogenesis.

RNA FAMILY

Mechanisms of action of ncRNAs

Short non-coding RNA

Composition: small interfering RNAs, piwi-interacting RNAs, and miRNAs.

Origin: transcribed as long precursors in which miRNA-containing hairpins are cleaved by the sequential actions of the DROSHA-DGCR8 microprocessor in the nucleus and the DICER-TRBP complex in the cytoplasm.

Size: ~22nt

Function: binds to Argonaute proteins to form the RNA-induced silencing complex, which mediates target-gene silencing by mRNA degradation or translation inhibition.

Mechanism: MiRNA binding sites have been identified in 3’ and 5’ untranslated regions, introns, as well as exonic regions of protein-coding mRNAs and lncRNAs.

Others:

  1. each miRNA can regulate hundreds of mRNAs, often targeting whole pathways.

  2. miRNA families have identical seed sequences, likely sharing most targets. The result is a complex network that may be necessary to stabilize central pathways, often displaying high redundancy.

    Long non-coding RNAs

    Characteristics: there are a few examples of lncRNAs displaying a conserved primary sequence, but conservation is generally weak. The secondary structure of lncRNAs is often conserved, suggesting that structural constraints may be more relevant than the nucleotide sequence in maintaining function. While many lncRNAs act in trans, leaving the site of transcription and executing various cellular processes throughout the cell, others work in cis, affecting nearby genes’ expression and chromatin state.

    Function:

  3. Some cis-acting lncRNAs regulate the expression of neighboring genes by recruiting regulatory factors to the originating loci, thereby modulating their function. A prototype of this class of lncRNAs is represented by XIST (X-inactive specific transcript).

  4. For other lncRNAs such as Airn or Blustr, the transcription or splicing of the lncRNA and not the transcript itself elicits the regulation of gene expression.

  5. In other lncRNAs, such as lincRNA-p21, the functional elements are only the DNA sequences within the promoter, regardless of the encoded RNA or its generation.

    Categories:

  6. LncRNAs can bring together transcriptional repressors and activators, modulating the rates of RNA Polymerase II initiation and elongation, interacting with various complexes, such as Polycomb Repressive Complex 1 or 2.

  7. Some nuclear lncRNAs have been implicated in maintaining nuclear bodies, such as atomic speckles, built on the architectural lncRNA, NEAT1.
  8. Some antisense lncRNAs can base-pair with sense-mRNAs, altering splice-site recognition and spliceosome recruitment.
  9. Other lncRNAs, such as MALAT1 (metastasis-associated lung adenocarcinoma transcript 1), do not hybridize with the target mRNA but can affect mRNA splicing through cooperation with the splicing machinery.
  10. Some lncRNAs act as a molecular scaffold, such as H19, which favors mRNA degradation mediated by the protein KSRP of myogenin.
  11. Others bind their complementary sense transcripts and mask miRNA binding sites, such as BACE1 antisense that protects BACE1 from miR4R85-5p inhibition.
  12. Several lncRNAs act as competing endogenous RNAs (ceRNAs), sponging miRNAs, and possibly other regulatory factors. For example, lincMD1 is encoded by the genomic locus containing the miR-206 and miR-133b and works as ceRNA for miR-133 and miR-135.
  13. LncRNAs can also affect gene expression at the posttranslational level, inducing ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis. For example, HOTAIR, in addition to its epi-genetic function, can bind to E3 ubiquitin-ligases bearing RNA-binding domains, along with their respective ubiquitination substrates, facilitating their ubiquitination and degradation.
  14. Cir-cRNAs, which are the product of back-splicing events and can accumulate at relatively high levels, act as ceRNA (miRNA sponges). They can also modulate RNA transcription, splicing, turnover, and translation and may have protein-coding potential.

Epitranscriptome

Regulatory RNAs in the Circulation

Increasing evidence shows that cells package and export different molecules, including regRNAs, in extracellular vesicles. These are taken up by recipient cells, where their cargo can induce expressional and functional changes.

Regulatory RNAs in the Cardiac Hypertrophy

Regulatory RNAs in the Cardiac Inflammation

Regulatory RNAs in Cardiac Regeneration

Regulatory RNAs in the Vascular System

Supplement: Something interesting

  1. These should be intended as operative categories, given that the distinction between coding and noncoding RNAs is sometimes blurred, with several cases of RNA species displaying dual roles encoding micro-proteins (less than 100 amino acids). Accordingly, the genomewide analysis of heart translatomes, characterized using ribosome profiling, identified hundreds of microproteins expressed from both lncRNAs and circRNAs.
  2. Noncoding RNAs are classified for practical reasons according to their size, less or more than 200 nucleotides long, into short- and long-ncRNAs, respectively.
  3. Regulatory RNAs can be subjected to methylation, the most important being N6-methyladenosine.
  4. miRNAs targeting the five ′- the untranslated region can induce gene expression.
  5. Though virtually all ncRNAs display at least one putative miRNA binding site, only a few are expressed at levels sufficiently high to operate as ceRNAs.
  6. Circulating regRNA profiles have also been reported to change in response to environmental and lifestyle factors, such as exercise, diet, and circadian rhythm.
  7. Common mechanisms of successful cardiac regeneration seen in lower vertebrates and neonatal mice include controlled inflammation and matrix remodeling centering around cardiomyocyte dedifferentiation and proliferation. In contrast, new cardiomyocyte formation resulting from endogenous differentiation of progenitor cells after an injury has been questioned lately.
  8. Coronary vessel remodeling contributes to impaired myocardial contractility. In contrast, peripheral vascular remodeling results in decreased compliance, increased resistance, and reduced capacitance in the arterial circulation, thus increasing the afterload and exacerbating heart failure.
  9. Circular RNAs are expressed and regulated in the vascular system, although their role in heart failure development is still poorly known.
  10. Endothelial lncRNAs and circRNAs are regulated by hypoxia and may contribute to regulating fibrosis.
  11. Given their relative cell-type specific expression and tight temporal and spatial regulation, regRNAs make attractive therapeutic targets and biomarkers for heart failure.

  12. Intriguingly, most of the lncRNA studies described scaffold-based mechanisms (“sponge effect”), in which they prevent miRNAs from exerting their roles on mRNAs.

    Questions: Something to be solved

  13. On the other hand, protein-coding sequences display evidence of other embedded functions, as indicated by constraints on synonymous codon usage.

    New words

    enormous;nomenclature;attenuate;scavenge;dispensable;pivotal;consecutive;initiatives;indispensable;postulate;consensus;paramount;plausible;subtle;trivial;putative;

    References

entry.title: 定量资料的统计描述、参数估计和假设检验基础
entry.content:
频数分布表与分布图

频数分布表
直方图
分布态势

平均数

均数

$$ G = {\ln ^{ - 1}}\left[ {\left( {\ln {X_1} + ... + \ln {X_n}} \right)/n} \right] = {\ln ^{ - 1}}\left[ {\sum\limits_{i = 1}^n {{X_n}} /n} \right] $$

中位数
百分位数

$$ {P_x} = {L_x} + {{{i_x}} \over {{f_x}}}\left( {nX\% - \sum {{f_L}} } \right) $$

变异指标

方差

$$ {S^2} = {{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^n {{{\left( {{X_i} - \overline X } \right)}^2}} } \over {n - 1}} $$

标准差

$$ S = \sqrt {{{\sum\limits_{i = 1}^n {{X_{\rm{i}}}^2 - {{\left( {\sum\limits_{i = 1}^n {{X_i}} } \right)}^2}/n} } \over {n - 1}}} $$

变异系数

$$ CV = {S \over {\overline X }}{\rm{ \times }}100\% $$

正态分布及其应用

正态分布的概念

$$ f\left( X \right) = {1 \over {\sigma \sqrt {2\pi } }}{e^{ - {{\left( {X - \mu } \right)}^2}/\left( {2{\sigma ^2}} \right)}} $$

$$ X \sim N\left( {\mu ,{\sigma ^2}} \right) $$

标准正态分布（Z分布）

$$ Z = \left( {{{X - \mu } \over \sigma }} \right) $$

正态分布的判定
医学参考值的估计

$$ 双侧： < \overline X \pm {Z_{{\alpha \over 2}}}S $$

$$ 单侧： < \overline X - {Z_\alpha }S 或 > \overline X + {Z_\alpha }S $$

抽样和抽样误差

中心极限定理
标准误

$$ {\sigma _{\overline X }} = {\sigma \over {\sqrt {\rm{n}} }} $$

$$ {S_{\overline X }} = {S \over {\sqrt {\rm{n}} }} $$

Student-t 分布

$$ {\rm{t}} = {{\overline X - \mu } \over {{S_{\overline X }}}} = {{\overline X - \mu } \over {{S \over {\sqrt n }}}},v = n - 1 $$

计算总体可信区间

$$ 双侧（1-α）可信区间：\overline X - {t_{{\alpha \over 2},v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }} < \mu < \overline X + {t_{{\alpha \over 2},v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }} $$

$$ 单侧（1-α）可信区间：\mu < \overline X + {t_{\alpha ,v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }}或\mu > \overline X - {t_{\alpha ,v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }} $$

$$ 双侧（1-α）可信区间：\left( {\overline X \pm {Z_{{\alpha \over 2},v}}{\sigma \over {\sqrt n }}} \right)或\left( {\overline X \pm {Z_{{\alpha \over 2},v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }}} \right) $$

$$ 单侧（1-α）可信区间：\mu > \overline X - {Z_{{\alpha},v}}{\sigma \over {\sqrt n }}或\mu > \overline X - {Z_{{\alpha},v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }} $$

$$ 单侧（1-α）可信区间：\mu < \overline X + {Z_{{\alpha},v}}{\sigma \over {\sqrt n }}或\mu < \overline X + {Z_{{\alpha},v}}{S \over {\sqrt n }} $$

entry.title: 第三期·专题圆桌会
entry.content:
2023年4月16日上午，由长学制学生第二党支部举办，其他两个兄弟党支部共同参与的“临床分享圆桌会”在中山大学北校区31层博士生宿舍楼成功举行。支委班子采取了理论学习+专题分享拼盘的创新形式，会上会后收到热烈反响。会议首先由黄渝琴同志首先领学学院党委理论学习中心组下发的3月份学习材料，随后集体观看《一百堂党课·青蒿素和屠呦呦》视频，加深了对同学们对医者身份的认同感，对人民群众日益增长的医疗需要的认识，激发了支部党员同志刻苦求学、认真行医，为“健康中国2030”战略努力奋斗的决心和热情。随后特别嘉宾—来自孙逸仙纪念医院妇科的龙腾飞主治医生，与同学们分享了从湖南到北京再到广州一路成长求学的经历，为同学们的选择二级学科、选择就业环境、科研提升路径、职业生涯发展等方面提出宝贵经验，帮助大家少走弯路，会上陈梓熠、庞晓白等同学分别就关心的就业城市、科研能力提升等问题向龙老师提问，龙医生都耐心地解答给出了自己的看法，鼓励同学们勇于选择、善于选择。最后由中山大学党委组织部专职组织员万海峰老师向龙腾飞医生颁发讲学证书并对会议做点评。万老师肯定了支委班子对活动的筹备工作是完备得当的，肯定了支部响应学校“一融双高”号召的积极性，鼓励支部继续开展系列活动，同时与同学们分享了自己听取龙医生分享后的心得体会，并鼓励青年党员同志能够像龙腾飞老师一样敢闯敢做，阳光开朗。会议由党支部副书记陈俞昆同志主持。

万海峰老师、龙腾飞老师与同学们合影留念
